title: Synthetic Data Generation and Analysis
text:
This project demonstrates basic synthetic data generation and analysis using Python.




Code
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns

# Set random seed for reproducibility
np.random.seed(42)

# Generate synthetic student test score data
def generate_student_scores(num_students=100):
    # Simulate scores for three different subjects
    math_scores = np.random.normal(loc=75, scale=10, size=num_students)
    science_scores = math_scores + np.random.normal(loc=5, scale=5, size=num_students)
    english_scores = np.random.normal(loc=70, scale=12, size=num_students)
    
    # Create a DataFrame
    student_data = pd.DataFrame({
        'Student_ID': range(1, num_students + 1),
        'Math_Score': np.round(math_scores, 2),
        'Science_Score': np.round(science_scores, 2),
        'English_Score': np.round(english_scores, 2)
    })
    
    return student_data

# Generate the synthetic dataset
students_df = generate_student_scores()

# Descriptive Statistics
print("Descriptive Statistics:")
print(students_df.describe())

# Visualization of Score Distributions
plt.figure(figsize=(12, 4))

# Subplot 1: Histogram of Scores
plt.subplot(1, 2, 1)
students_df[['Math_Score', 'Science_Score', 'English_Score']].hist(bins=15, ax=plt.gca())
plt.title('Distribution of Test Scores')
plt.tight_layout()

# Subplot 2: Box Plot of Scores
plt.subplot(1, 2, 2)
sns.boxplot(data=students_df[['Math_Score', 'Science_Score', 'English_Score']])
plt.title('Box Plot of Test Scores')
plt.tight_layout()

plt.show()

# Correlation Analysis
correlation_matrix = students_df[['Math_Score', 'Science_Score', 'English_Score']].corr()
print("\nCorrelation Matrix:")
print(correlation_matrix)

# Correlation Heatmap
plt.figure(figsize=(8, 6))
sns.heatmap(correlation_matrix, annot=True, cmap='coolwarm', center=0)
plt.title('Correlation Heatmap of Test Scores')
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()


Descriptive Statistics:
       Student_ID  Math_Score  Science_Score  English_Score
count  100.000000  100.000000     100.000000     100.000000
mean    50.500000   73.961600      79.072900      70.780200
std     29.011492    9.082117       9.664472      13.011703
min      1.000000   48.800000      55.190000      31.100000
25%     25.750000   68.987500      73.195000      62.135000
50%     50.500000   73.730000      78.040000      71.170000
75%     75.250000   79.062500      84.557500      78.457500
max    100.000000   93.520000     105.220000     116.230000


/tmp/ipykernel_170946/3181019396.py:38: UserWarning:

To output multiple subplots, the figure containing the passed axes is being cleared.











Correlation Matrix:
               Math_Score  Science_Score  English_Score
Math_Score       1.000000       0.872429       0.190887
Science_Score    0.872429       1.000000       0.161229
English_Score    0.190887       0.161229       1.000000














Code
# Calculate additional insights
def analyze_student_scores(df):
    # Calculate overall performance
    df['Average_Score'] = df[['Math_Score', 'Science_Score', 'English_Score']].mean(axis=1)
    
    # Identify top and bottom performers
    top_students = df.nlargest(5, 'Average_Score')
    bottom_students = df.nsmallest(5, 'Average_Score')
    
    print("\nTop 5 Students:")
    print(top_students)
    
    print("\nBottom 5 Students:")
    print(bottom_students)
    
    return df

# Perform analysis
students_df = analyze_student_scores(students_df)



Top 5 Students:
    Student_ID  Math_Score  Science_Score  English_Score  Average_Score
20          21       89.66          98.61          97.78      95.350000
9           10       80.43          85.05         116.23      93.903333
6            7       90.79         105.22          76.18      90.730000
82          83       89.78          89.42          89.03      89.410000
31          32       93.52          98.87          72.60      88.330000

Bottom 5 Students:
    Student_ID  Math_Score  Science_Score  English_Score  Average_Score
74          75       48.80          55.19          58.22      54.070000
62          63       63.94          74.73          31.10      56.590000
23          24       60.75          58.74          50.65      56.713333
44          45       60.21          66.51          55.60      60.773333
63          64       63.04          63.93          57.71      61.560000






Demonstrates synthetic data generation techniques
Provides statistical analysis of generated data
Creates visualizations to explore data distributions
Shows correlation between different subject scores





Uses normal distribution to simulate realistic score variations
Introduces correlations between subject scores
Provides multiple perspectives on the synthetic dataset

title: Synthetic Data Generation and Analysis
text:
Code
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns

# Set random seed for reproducibility
np.random.seed(42)

# Generate synthetic student test score data
def generate_student_scores(num_students=100):
    # Simulate scores for three different subjects
    math_scores = np.random.normal(loc=75, scale=10, size=num_students)
    science_scores = math_scores + np.random.normal(loc=5, scale=5, size=num_students)
    english_scores = np.random.normal(loc=70, scale=12, size=num_students)
    
    # Create a DataFrame
    student_data = pd.DataFrame({
        'Student_ID': range(1, num_students + 1),
        'Math_Score': np.round(math_scores, 2),
        'Science_Score': np.round(science_scores, 2),
        'English_Score': np.round(english_scores, 2)
    })
    
    return student_data

# Generate the synthetic dataset
students_df = generate_student_scores()

# Descriptive Statistics
print("Descriptive Statistics:")
print(students_df.describe())

# Visualization of Score Distributions
plt.figure(figsize=(12, 4))

# Subplot 1: Histogram of Scores

students_df[['Math_Score', 'Science_Score', 'English_Score']].hist(bins=15, ax=plt.gca())

title: Awesome Sites! üòé
text:
As developers, we‚Äôre constantly searching for high-quality resources to enhance our skills and discover new tools. The ‚Äúawesome‚Äù lists on GitHub have become a cornerstone of community-curated knowledge sharing. These collections are meticulously maintained by passionate developers worldwide, offering carefully selected resources across various technological domains.
The concept started with Sindre Sorhus‚Äôs original awesome list, which has since spawned thousands of specialized collections. These lists follow strict guidelines to ensure quality and relevance, making them invaluable for both beginners and experienced developers.





Awesome Machine Learning

A comprehensive collection of ML frameworks, libraries, and software
Covers multiple programming languages including Python, R, Java, and more
Includes sections on computer vision, natural language processing, and deep learning






Awesome Python

Essential Python frameworks, libraries, and resources
Organized by application domain (web development, data science, testing, etc.)
Perfect for both Python beginners and advanced developers

Awesome Rust

Curated resources for Rust programming language
Applications, development tools, and learning materials
Great for those interested in systems programming and performance






Awesome Embedded

Resources for embedded systems development
Hardware platforms, tools, and frameworks
Essential for IoT and hardware developers

Awesome Self Hosted

Software solutions you can host on your own servers
Alternatives to popular cloud services
Perfect for privacy-conscious developers and organizations






Awesome Static Site Generators

Tools for building modern static websites
Frameworks across multiple programming languages
Includes JAMstack resources and deployment options






Awesome Prompts

Collection of effective prompts for AI models
Best practices for prompt engineering
Examples for various use cases and applications






To keep track of changes and new additions to these collections, I recommend using Track Awesome List. This tool helps you monitor updates to your favorite awesome lists and discover new resources regularly.



These curated collections represent countless hours of community effort to organize and validate the best resources in each field. Whether you‚Äôre exploring a new technology or deepening your expertise in a familiar domain, these awesome lists are invaluable starting points for your journey.
Remember to contribute back to these collections if you discover valuable resources that aren‚Äôt already included. The strength of these lists comes from active community participation and sharing.
‚Äì Last updated: November 2024-

Welcome to my website! üëãüèæ

My name is Chaance Graves. Welcome to my website, where I share my blog on topics and projects that I‚Äôve worked on or still tinkering with. I‚Äôm a creative problem solver eager to implement solutions to many issues foreseen in our modern society. In addition to that, I am also a big advocate for giving back to others who aspire to follow a path like mine.

title: Are you getting started learning Python? üêç
text:
Are you new to programming? Have questions about which language would be a good one to start?
Choosing which programming language to learn is more a personal preference depending on what project and solution you‚Äôre looking to achieve. However, for a beginner, you have lots of flexibility to experiment with which one is right for you. One programming language I enjoy working with and others have found helpful is Python. I recommend installing Python 3 to have more community support to be developed and used for years to come.
There are likely millions of developers worldwide using Python to build projects, tools and using it to teach others the fundamentals of programming. You can do all kinds of other fantastic work in a multitude of domains.

Example applications:

Web applications
Machine Learning / Deep learning
Automating weekly emails
Setting up jobs to update a spreadsheet
etc.



Helpful online resources & books
You can find plentiful resources to teach yourself Python or pair with a small group to work on projects!
Codeacademy: Codeacademy offers free code tutorials that are very popular for a good reason. The tutorials should give you a good idea of what it‚Äôs like to code Python with hands-on lessons to write code.
Learn Python the Hard Way by Zed Shaw: This book is well received and aims to teach beginners how to read and write basic Python to understand other books on Python. It is high quality which I recommend regardless of where your current skill is. You can try the free sample to see if it would work for you.
Real Python: This website offers in-depth tutorials to learn any aspect of Python you may be curious to explore. Check it out and keep a list of articles for future reference!
Automate the boring stuff with Python by Al Sweigart: This is an enjoyable read and practical for anyone who is currently working a tedious, routine job! He also offers a video course provided through Udemy.
Udemy: You can find all sorts of courses and projects offered on this online education website. They range from beginner to advanced and have instructors teaching financial topics such as predicting stock prices, data science, full-stack web development, and more.
I‚Äôm confident your programming journey will be well on its way towards success. Feel free to discuss any other valuable resources or projects you‚Äôve discovered learning Python. üëåüèæ

title: Programming Syntax Comparisons and Examples

title: Programming Syntax Comparisons and Examples
Programming Syntax Comparisons and Examples
Programming Syntax Comparisons and Examples
Programming Syntax Comparisons and Examples
Programming Syntax Comparisons and Examples
text:
Key Takeaways

Python excels in readability and has powerful list comprehensions
Rust provides strong safety guarantees and explicit error handling
JavaScript offers flexible object handling and functional programming features

title: Programming Syntax Comparisons and Examples
text:
Notes for Future Reference

Python‚Äôs type hints are optional but helpful for documentation
Rust‚Äôs ownership system requires explicit handling of references
JavaScript‚Äôs flexibility can be both a blessing and a curse

Remember to check the official documentation for each language for best practices and more detailed explanations: - Python Docs - Rust Book - MDN JavaScript

title: Household Energy Consumption Analysis
text:
This project simulates and analyzes household energy consumption across different seasons and appliance types.




Code
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns

# Set random seed for reproducibility
np.random.seed(42)

# Generate synthetic energy consumption data
seasons = ['Winter', 'Spring', 'Summer', 'Autumn']
appliances = ['Heating', 'Cooling', 'Lighting', 'Appliances']

# Create a dictionary to store our data
energy_data = {
    'Season': [],
    'Appliance': [],
    'Energy_Consumption': []
}

# Simulate energy consumption with seasonal variations
for season in seasons:
    for appliance in appliances:
        # Different base consumption and variance for each appliance and season
        if appliance == 'Heating':
            base = 50 if season in ['Winter', 'Autumn'] else 20
            variance = 15
        elif appliance == 'Cooling':
            base = 50 if season in ['Summer'] else 20
            variance = 15
        elif appliance == 'Lighting':
            base = 30 if season in ['Winter'] else 20
            variance = 10
        else:  # General Appliances
            base = 25
            variance = 5
        
        # Generate 30 data points (representing days in a month)
        consumption = np.random.normal(base, variance, 30)
        
        # Add to our data structure
        energy_data['Season'].extend([season] * 30)
        energy_data['Appliance'].extend([appliance] * 30)
        energy_data['Energy_Consumption'].extend(consumption)

# Convert to DataFrame
df = pd.DataFrame(energy_data)

# Box plot of energy consumption by season and appliance
plt.figure(figsize=(12, 6))
sns.boxplot(x='Season', y='Energy_Consumption', hue='Appliance', data=df)
plt.title('Energy Consumption by Season and Appliance')
plt.xlabel('Season')
plt.ylabel('Energy Consumption (kWh)')
plt.xticks(rotation=45)
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

# Calculate summary statistics
summary = df.groupby(['Season', 'Appliance'])['Energy_Consumption'].agg(['mean', 'std']).round(2)
print("Energy Consumption Summary:")
print(summary)









Energy Consumption Summary:
                    mean    std
Season Appliance               
Autumn Appliances  25.23   5.52
       Cooling     20.43  15.06
       Heating     53.42  14.89
       Lighting    19.43  11.89
Spring Appliances  25.24   5.19
       Cooling     24.18  14.21
       Heating     18.58  15.36
       Lighting    20.66  10.53
Summer Appliances  23.97   3.36
       Cooling     51.61  13.79
       Heating     17.85  17.38
       Lighting    22.82   7.77
Winter Appliances  24.90   4.54
       Cooling     18.18  13.97
       Heating     47.18  13.50
       Lighting    30.13   9.92







Code
# Pivot table for easier comparison
pivot_table = df.pivot_table(
    values='Energy_Consumption', 
    index='Season', 
    columns='Appliance', 
    aggfunc='mean'
).round(2)

plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6))
pivot_table.plot(kind='bar', ax=plt.gca())
plt.title('Average Energy Consumption by Season and Appliance')
plt.xlabel('Season')
plt.ylabel('Average Energy Consumption (kWh)')
plt.legend(title='Appliance', bbox_to_anchor=(1.05, 1), loc='upper left')
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

# Print the pivot table
print("\nAverage Energy Consumption by Season and Appliance:")
print(pivot_table)










Average Energy Consumption by Season and Appliance:
Appliance  Appliances  Cooling  Heating  Lighting
Season                                           
Autumn          25.23    20.43    53.42     19.43
Spring          25.24    24.18    18.58     20.66
Summer          23.97    51.61    17.85     22.82
Winter          24.90    18.18    47.18     30.13






Energy consumption varies significantly across seasons and appliances.
Heating and cooling show the most pronounced seasonal variations.
The analysis provides insights into potential energy-saving strategies.





Focus on heating efficiency during winter months
Implement smart cooling strategies in summer
Consider energy-efficient lighting solutions

title: Household Energy Consumption Analysis
text:
Code
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns

# Set random seed for reproducibility
np.random.seed(42)

# Generate synthetic energy consumption data
seasons = ['Winter', 'Spring', 'Summer', 'Autumn']
appliances = ['Heating', 'Cooling', 'Lighting', 'Appliances']

# Create a dictionary to store our data
energy_data = {
    'Season': [],
    'Appliance': [],
    'Energy_Consumption': []
}

# Simulate energy consumption with seasonal variations
for season in seasons:
    for appliance in appliances:
        # Different base consumption and variance for each appliance and season
        if appliance == 'Heating':
            base = 50 if season in ['Winter', 'Autumn'] else 20
            variance = 15
        elif appliance == 'Cooling':
            base = 50 if season in ['Summer'] else 20
            variance = 15
        elif appliance == 'Lighting':
            base = 30 if season in ['Winter'] else 20
            variance = 10
        else:  # General Appliances
            base = 25
            variance = 5
        
        # Generate 30 data points (representing days in a month)
        consumption = np.random.normal(base, variance, 30)
        
        # Add to our data structure
        energy_data['Season'].extend([season] * 30)
        energy_data['Appliance'].extend([appliance] * 30)
        energy_data['Energy_Consumption'].extend(consumption)

# Convert to DataFrame
df = pd.DataFrame(energy_data)

# Box plot of energy consumption by season and appliance
plt.figure(figsize=(12, 6))
sns.boxplot(x='Season', y='Energy_Consumption', hue='Appliance', data=df)
plt.title('Energy Consumption by Season and Appliance')
plt.xlabel('Season')
plt.ylabel('Energy Consumption (kWh)')

print(summary)
